div.head: The comedy named the several wits. The wise wit, the wild wit, the choleric wit, the humble wit.

list.head: The names of the persons.
list.item: Doctor freedom, a doctor of physic.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: This play I do present to lady wits,
And hope the wit, each several humour fits;
For though all wit, be wit, as of wit kind,
Yet different be, as men, not of one mind;
For different men, hath different minds we know,
So different wits, in different humours flow.
The choleric wit is rough, and salt as brine,
The humble wit flows smooth, in a straight line:
A wise wit flows in streams, fresh, pure and clear,
Where neither weeds, nor troubled waves appear:
But a wild wit in every ditch doth flow,
And with the mud doth soul, and filthy grow.

div.head: The comedy named the several wits.
Act i.
Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, and her maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, monsieur importunate is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Madam. Caprisia.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, I would receive no visits today.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I did tell him that you desired to be excused; but he said, he would not excuse you, for he must see you.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: Go tell him I have taken physic.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I did tell him so, but he said, he would stay until it had done working.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: I would it were working in his belly.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and monsieur bon compaignon.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Lady, hearing of your great wit, I am come to prove report.

sp.speaker: Madam. Volante.
sp.p: You will find him a liar, sir.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: I had rather report should be a liar, than I a lover.

sp.speaker: Madam. Volante.
sp.p: Why, than we agree in a mind, for I had rather be thought a fool, than to be troubled with a fool's company.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: You need not be troubled with that, for love is strongest absented.

sp.speaker: Madam. Volante.
sp.p: O! but there is an old proverb, that love will break through stonewalls, wherefore if you be in love, you will haunt me like a fairy, no locks nor bolts will keep you out, for fairy love will creep through a crevice.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Faith lady! I find now, that love is the Queen of fairies, for it hath crept through the keyhole of my ears, and hath got into my head, and their dances such roundelays, as makes my brain dizzy.

sp.speaker: Madam. Volante.
sp.p: If once your brain begins to be dizzy, your senses will stagger, and your reason will fall down from its feat, and when the reason is displaced, and the wit is distempered, the mind become mad, and to prevent the mischief that may follow, I will depart in time.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, as at the door meets Monsieur importunate, he stops her passage.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: You shall not pass, until you have paid me a tribute.

sp.speaker: Madam. Caprisia.
sp.p: What tribute?

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: A kiss.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: I will pay no such tribute, for I will bring such a number of words armed with such strong reasons, as they shall make my way.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: Your words will prove poor pilgrims, which come to offer at the altar of my lips.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: Nay, rather than so, they shall come as humble petitioners, and as it were, kneeling at your heart, shall with innocency beg for gentle civility.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: I will shut the gates of my ears against them, and my lips as a bar shall force them back, being a precise factious rout.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: Satire shall lead my sharp words on, break open those gates, and anger like consuming fire shall both destroy your will and base desire.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: I will try that.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: But I will rather make a safe retreat, than venture, lest your rude strength might overcome my words.

div.stage: She goeth back, he follows her

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: I will march after, at the heels of you.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Doltche, and monsieur compliment.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Sir, you praise me so much, as I may doubt, or rather believe you flatter me; for it is not possible to be so rare a creature, as you express me to be, unless I were something divine, perchance I may be worthy of some of your inferior praises, but not all your high and mighty ones.

sp.speaker: Monsieur compliment.
sp.p: You are more than either I can express, or think you to be.

sp.speaker: Mad. Doltche.
sp.p: Nay, if I be above your thoughts, I am above your delight; for mankind takes no great pleasure in that they comprehend not.

sp.speaker: Mons. compliment.
sp.p: I believe you do not comprehend how well I love you.

sp.speaker: Mad. Doltche.
sp.p: No truly, for love is like infinite, it hath no circumference, wherefore I will not trouble myself in loves ways, since it is an endless journey.

sp.speaker: Mons. compliment.
sp.p: But surely, lady, though you cannot find that worth in me, as merits your esteem and affection, yet you will favour me for your lather's command, and love me for his desire.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: If my father desires me to die, I shall satisfy his desire, for it is in my power to take away my own life, when I will; but it is not in my power to love those my father would have me; for love is not to be commanded, nor directed, nor governed, nor prescribed, for love is free, and not to be controlled; also I may marry a man my father desires me, but sure my father will not desire, nor command me to marry, if I cannot love the man he would have me marry, as I ought to do a husband.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter madam. Caprisia, and a grave matron.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel Caprisia, there is a gentleman, one of my acquaintance doth desire to see you.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: He desires more than I do, for I never see a man, but I wish a vail before my sight, or one before his.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Have you taken a surfeit of eyes, as you hate to look on a man's face.

sp.speaker: Madam. Capris.
sp.p: Yes, of wanton eyes, that skips from face to face, which makes me love the blind.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I wonder whether the soul may be satisfied, or surfeit as the senses do.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: The thoughts, passions and appetites, which are begotten betwixt the soul and senses, will surfeit, if they be overfed.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: What is that lady that is overfed?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: A fools-head.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: How can a fool's head be overfed?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: With hearing and seeing more than it can digest into understanding.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: You have not such a head, lady, for your head is so full of wit, as it perpetually flows through your lips; yet whatsoever it doth receive, the son of reason doth digest, and refines into spirits of senses.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I must confess, my tongue is more fertile than my brain, the which comes more words from the one, than sense or reason from the other; but lest I should overfill your ears with my idle talks, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: And I will follow you, for my ears are unsatisfied, having but a taste of her wit, which makes a greater appetite.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter madamosel solid, monsieur profession, and monsieur Comorade his friend.

sp.speaker: Monsieur procession.
sp.p: Lady, you live, as if you lived not, living so solitary a life.

sp.speaker: Lady solid.
sp.p:
Indeed, few doth live as they should, that is, to live within themselves; for the soul, which is the supreme part of the life, is never at home, but goeth wandering about, from place to place, from person to person, and so from one thing to another, and not only the soul wanders thus; but all the family of the soul, as the thoughts and passions; for should any thing knock at the gates of the soul, which are the senses, or enter the chambers of the soul, which is the heart, and the head, they would find them empty, for the thoughts and passions, which passions are of the bedchamber, which is, the heart and presence-chamber, which is, the head wherein they ought to wait, are for the most part, all gone abroad; as for the thoughts, they are gone to inquire news, walking and running into every village, town, city and country, and kingdom, all to inquire what such and such persons said or acted, and the particular affairs of every particular person, and every particular family, as whether they increase with riches, or decay with poverty; whether they live beyond their means, or keep within their compass; what men and women are in love, who are constant, and who are false; what contracts are signed, or what contracts are broken; who marries, and who lives single lives; who is happy in marriage, and who is not; what children is born, who hath children, and who hath none; who is handsome, and who is ill-favoured; who dies, and of what diseases they died of; whether they left wealth or were poor, or who were their heirs,
or executors; who are widowers, widows or orphans; who hath losses, crosses and misfortunes, who is in favour or disgrace with such princes or states; who is at law, what suits there is lost or gained; what bribes were given and taken, who was arrested, or imprisoned for debts; or set in the pillory or stocks for disorder, or cast into the counter for misdemeanour; who is accused or imprisoned for robbery, murder or treason; who is condemned or reprieved; what deaths they died, or torments endured; what laws there is made, repealed or broke; what officers or magistrates there are made, placed or displaced, or put out; what factions or bruleries there is, what leagues and associates there is made betwixt states and princes; what wars, or peace there is, or like to be betwixt such or such kingdoms; what triumphs, or shows there is, or like to be; what mountebanks, tumblers, and dancers there is; what strange birds, beasts or monsters there is to be seen; what drunkards, bawds and whores there is, what da●●s hath been sought, and the cause of their quarrels; who hath lost at play, and who hath won, what new fashions there is; what stuffs, silks, laces, and embroideries there is; what lords, ladies, knights or esquires hath new coaches or liveries; what rich clothes they had, or have; what church is most frequented, what balls, masks, plays and feasts there is, or like to be, and many the like vain, idle, unuseful, unprofitable inquiries, observations and entertainments; their thoughts employs and wa●ts their time with: as for the passions and affections, they are as much abroad, as the rest of the thoughts, some being with such and such men, or such and such women, as first with one, and then with another; or with such a house, or houses, or lands, or with such jewels, or place, or hangings, or pictures, or the like; also the passions and affections wander; amongst beasts, as with such a horse, dog, monkey, or the like; or with birds, as with such a hawk, cock of the game, or prating parrot, or singing linnet, or the like; or the passions and affections are attending, watching, or seeking after such or such offices or commands, governments or titles; nay, the very soul itself goeth after such and such designs, so as it doth, as it were, run away from itself, it follows the world, and worldly things, but never draws any benefit to itself, but that soul that keeps at home, which very few souls doth; employs itself, for itself, it only views the world for knowledge, yet so, as it looks, as out of a window on a prospect, it uses the world out of necessity, but not serves the world out of slavery; it is industrious for its own tranquillity, fame and everlasting life, for which it leaves nothing unsought, or undone, is a wise soul.

sp.speaker: Monsieur profession.
sp.p: Madam, my soul is tied to your soul, with such an undissolvable knot of affection, that nothing, no, not death can lose it, nor break it asunder; wherefore, wheresoever your soul doth go, thine will follow it, and bear it company.

sp.speaker: Madam solid.
sp.p: Then your soul will be incognita, for my soul will not know whether your soul will be with it, or not.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Comorade.
sp.p: Faith Thom. it's happy for thy soul, to be drawn by her magnetic soul; for that may draw, lead or direct thy soul to heaven; otherwise thy soul will fall into hell with the pressure of they sins, for thy soul is as heavy, as crime can make it.

sp.speaker: Mons. Prof.
sp.p:
Why, than the devil would have found my soul an honest soul, in being full weight, his true coin, and the right stamp of his picture, or figure,
for which he would have used my soul well, and if heaven gives me not this, lady, hell take me.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Comorade.
sp.p: Certainly you may be the devil's guest, but whether you will be the lady's husband, it is to be doubted.

sp.speaker: Mons. profession.
sp.p: Well, I will do my endeavour to get her, and more, a man cannot do.

div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, and monsieur importunate.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: You are the rarest beauty, and greatest wit in the world.

sp.speaker: Mad. Capris.
sp.p: Wit is like beauty, and beauty is oftener created in the fancy, than the face; so wit oftener by opinion, than in the brain, not, but surely there may be a real beauty, and so a real wit, yet that real wit, is no wit to the ignorant, no more than beauty to the blind, for the wit is lost to the understanding, as beauty is lost to the eyes, and it is not in nature to give, what is not in nature to receive, nor in nature to show what is not in nature to be seen; so there must be eyes to see beauty, and ears to hear wit, and understanding to judge of both, and you have neither judgements eyes, nor understandings ears, nor rational sense.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: Why, than you have neither beauty nor wit.

sp.speaker: Mad. Capris.
sp.p: I have both, but your commendations are from report; for fools speaks by rote, as parrots do.

sp.speaker: Monsieur importunate.
sp.p: She is like a bee loaded with sweet honey, but her tongue is the sting, that blisters all it strikes on.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and monsieur bon compaignon.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Lady, why are you so silent.

sp.speaker: Madam Volante.
sp.p: Why soul I speak to those that understands me not.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Why? are you so difficult to be understood.

sp.speaker: Mad. Volante.
sp.p: No, but understanding is so difficult to find.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: So, and since there is such a total decay of understanding in every brain, as there is none to be found, but in your own, you will make a new commonwealth in yours, where your thoughts, as wife magistrates, and good citizens, shall govern and traffic therein, and your words shall be as letters of mart, and your senses shall be as legate ambassadors that lives in other kingdoms, which takes instructions, and give intelligence, or rather your thoughts are destinies, and fates, and your words their several decrees.

sp.speaker: Mad. Volante.
sp.p: Do you think my thoughts can warrant laws, or can my words decree them?

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: I believe your thoughts are so wise and just, that whatsoever they allow of, must be best, and your words are so witty, rational; positive and powerful, as none can contradict them.

sp.speaker: Mad. Volante.
sp.p: Good sir, contradict yourself, or truth will contradict you.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Nay faith, I will never take the pains to contradict myself; let truth do what she will.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter madam la Mere, and her daughter madamosel Caprisia.

sp.speaker: Madam mere.
sp.p: Daughter, did you entertain the lady visit civilly?

sp.speaker: Mad. Capris.
sp.p: Yes mother, extraordinary civilly, for I gave her leave to entertain herself with her own discourse.

sp.speaker: Mad. mere.
sp.p: That was rudely.

sp.speaker: Mad. Capris.
sp.p: O no, for certainly it is the height of courtship to our sex, to let them talk all the talk themselves; for all women takes more delight to discourse themselves, than to hear another; and they are extremely pleased, if any listens, or at least seems to listen to them, for the truth is, that talking is one of the most luxurious appetites women have; wherefore I could not be more civiller, than to bar and restrain the effeminate nature in myself, to give her tongue liberty.

sp.speaker: Madam. Mere.
sp.p: But you should have spoken a word now, and then, as giving her civilly some breathing rest for her discourse to lean upon.

sp.speaker: Mad. Capris.
sp.p: Her speech was so strong, and long-winded, as it run with a full speed, without stop or stay, it neither need spur nor whip; the truth is it had been well, if it had been held in with the bridle of moderation, for it ran quite beyond the bounds of discretion, although sometimes it ran upon the uneven ways of slander, other times upon the stony ground of censure, and sometimes in the soul ways of immodesty, and often upon the furrows of nonsense; besides, it did usually skip over the hedges of truth, and certainly, if the necessities of nature, and the separations of neighbourhood, and the changes and intercourse of, and in the affairs of the world, and men did not forcibly stop, sometimes a woman's tongue, it would run as far as the confines of death.

sp.speaker: Mad. mere.
sp.p: But let me tell you daughter, your tongue is as sharp, as a serpent's sting, and will wound as cruelly and deadly where it bites.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: It proves my tongue a woman's tongue.

sp.speaker: Mad. mere.
sp.p: Why should a woman's tongue have the effects of a serpent's sting.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: The reason is evident, for the great serpent that tempted, and so perverted our grandmother eve in paradise, had a monstrous sting, and our grandmother whetted her tongue with his sting, and ever since, all her effeminate race hath tongues that stings.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Doltche, and monsieur bon compaignon.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Lady, monsieur Nobilissimo is so in love with you, as he cannot be happy, until you be his wife.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: I wonder he should be in love with me, since I have neither beauty to allure him, nor so much riches, as to entice him, nor wit to persuade him to marry me.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: But lady, you have virtue, good nature, sweet disposition, graceful behaviour, which are sufficient subjects for love to settle on, did you want what you mentioned, out you have all, not only what any man can with or desire with a wife, but you have as much as you can wish and desire to have yourself.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: I will rather be so vain, as to strive to believe you, than rudely to contradict you.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: It is neither erroneous, nor vain to believe a truth, lady.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Nor civil to make a doubt, sir; but I am obliged unto you for that, you help to cover my defects, and wants in nature, with your civil commendation, and your kind estimation of me.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter monsieur importunate, and madamosel Caprisia.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: My fair wit, you look as if you were angry with me.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: You dwell not so long in my mind, as to make me angry, my thoughts are strangers to your figures.

div.stage: She offers to go away, and he holds her from going.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Nay faith, now I have you, I will keep you perforce, until you pay me the kiss you owe me.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Let me go, for I had rather my eyes were eternally sealed up, my ears for ever stopped close from sound, than hear or see you.
I care not whether you hear, or see me, so you will kiss me.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Let me go, or otherwise my lips shall curse you, and my words being whetted with injury, are become so sharp, as they will wound you.

sp.speaker: Importunate
sp.p: I will keep you until your words begs for mercy in the most humblest style, and after the most mollifying manner.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Hell take you, or earth devour you like a beast, never to rise.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Love strike your heart with shooting through your eyes.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: May you be blown up with pride, until you burst into madness, may your thoughts be more troubled than rough waters, more raging than a tempest; may your senses feel no pleasure, your body find no rest, nor your life any peace.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: May you love me with a doting affection; may I be the only man you will embrace, and may you think me to be as handsome as Narcissus did himself.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: You appear to me in all the horrid shapes that fancy can invent.

sp.speaker: Madam mere.
sp.p: Why, how now daughter, always quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Can you blame me, when I am beset with rudeness, and assaulted with uncivil actions.

sp.speaker: Madam mere.
sp.p: Let her alone, monsieur importunate, for she is a very shrew.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, for all the shrews that ever nature made, you are the cursest one.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and a grave matron.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: I am not of the humour; as most women are, which is, to please themselves with thinking, or rather believing, that all men that looks on them, are in love with them: but I take pleasure, that all men that I look on, should think I am in love with them; which men will soon believe, being as self-conceited as women are.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But where is the pleasure, lady.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Why, in seeing their fantastical garbs, their strutting postures, their smiling faces, and the jackanapesly actions, and then I laugh in my mind, to think what fools they are, so as I make myself merry at their folly, and not at my own.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But men will appear as much jackanapeses, when they are in love with you, as if they thought you were in love with them, for all lovers are apish, more or less.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: I grant all lovers are, but those that think themselves beloved, appears more like the grave baboon, than the skipping jackanapes; for though their actions are as ridiculous, yet they are with more formality, as being more circumspectly foolish, or self-conceitedly vain.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Well, for all your derisions and jesting at men, I shall see you at onetime or other, shot with Cupid's arrow.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: By death's dart, you may; but never by love's arrow; for death hath power on me, though love hath none.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p:
There is an old saying, that time, importunity and opportunity, wins the chastest she, when those are joined with wealth and dignity; but
to yield to a lawful love, neither requires much time, nor pleading, if the suitors have but person, title and wealth, which women for the most part do prize, before valour, wisdom or honesty.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Women hath reason to prefer certainties before uncertainties; for men's persons, titles and wealths, are visible to their view and knowledge, but their valours, wisdoms and honesties, doth rest upon faith; for a coward may fight, and a fool may speak rationally, and act prudently sometimes, and a knave may appear an honest man.

sp.speaker: Matrons.
sp.p: They may so, but a valiant man, will never act the part of a coward; nor a wise man prove a fool, nor an honest man appear a knave.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: There can be no proof of any man's valour, wisdom or honesty, but at the day of his death, in aged years, whenas he hath passed the danger in wars, the trials in miseries, the malice of fortune, the temptations of pleasures, the enticements of vice, the heights of glory, the changes of life, provokers of passion, deluders of senses, torments of pain, or painful torments, and to choose a husband that hath had the trials, and experiences of all these, is to choose a husband out of the grave, and rather than I will marry death, I will live a maid, as long as I live, and when I die, let death do what he will with me.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter monsieur profession in mourning; then enters his friend, monsieur Comorade.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Comorade.
sp.p: Well met, I have travelled through all the town, and have inquired of every one I could speak to, and could neither hear of thee, nor see thee.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: It were happy for me, if I had neither ears nor eyes.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter, man?

div.stage: He observes his mourning and then starts.
Godsme! Now I perceive thou art in mourning: which of thy friends is dead?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: The chiefest friend I had, which mas my heart; for that is dead, being killed with my mistress' cruelty, and buried in her inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: I dare swear, not the whole heart; for every man's heart, is like a head of garlic, which may be divided into many several cloves: wherefore, cheer up, man; for it is but one clove, that death, or love, hath swallowed down into his stomach, to cure him of the wind-colic; and since thy heart hath so many cloves, thou mayst well spare him one, and be never the worse; but if it be buried, as you say, in your mistress's inconstancy; it is to be hoped it will be converted into the same inconstant humour, and that will cure the other part of thy heart.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: O! she was the saint of my thoughts, and the goddess of my soul.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Prithee let me be thy moral tutor, to instruct thee in the knowledge of truth, and to let thee know, that virtue is the true goddess, to which all men ought to bow to; and that youth, beauty and wealth, are sixth to be forsaken, when virtue comes in place; and virtue is constant, both to its principals and promises; wherefore, if thy mistress be inconstant, she cannot be virtuous, wherefore let her go.

div.stage: Monsieur profession fetches a great sigh, and goes out without speaking a word.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: I think his heart is dead in good earnest; for it hath no sense of what I have said.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Mere, and her daughter madamosel Caprisia.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Daughter, you have a sufficiency of wit and beauty, to get many lovers to choose a husband, if you had but patience to entertain, and prudence to keep them; but your being cross, will lose your lovers, as soon as your beauty hath taken them.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: It is no prize for a woman to have such lovers, that hath amorous natures; for it is their nature that drives them to her, and not the woman's beauty or wit, that draws them to her; and there is less force required to drive, than to draw; but the truth is, that most men hath such threadbare souls, as if the nap of their understanding were worn of; or indeed, their souls seems, as if there were never any woven thereon, as that nature hath made all their souls, thin and course, or as if time had moth-eaten them, which makes me, although not to hate you, yet to despise that sex; for men that should imitate the gods, yet are they worse than beasts, which makes me shun their beastly company.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Daughter, you speak and judge passionately, and passion can never reason well; for how is it possible, for reason to exercise its function, when passion opposes, and is too strong for it.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Truth may be delivered in passion, but not corrupted with passion; for truth is truth, howsoever it be divulged, or else it is no truth, but falsehood.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter monsieur perfection, and madamosel solid, dressed very fine.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: You are wondrous fine, today, madam.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: If I seem fine, today, I am obliged more to my fancy, than my wealth, for this finery.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: The truth is, you are so adjusted, so curiously accoutred, as I perceive, judgement and wit were joined associates in your dressing.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: I had rather be commended, or applauded for judgement and wit, than for wealth and beauty; for I had rather have my soul commended, than my person, or fortunes.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: Certainly, I believe you have a more rational soul, than any other of your sex have.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Alas? My soul is but a young soul, a mere novice soul, it wants growth, or my soul is like a house, which time the architectour hath newly begun to build; and the senses, which are the labourers, wants information and experience, which are the material for the rational soul to be built on, or with; but such materials as hath been brought in, I strive and endeavour to make the best, and most convenient use for a happy life.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: How say you? the best use for a good wife!

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: No, that little reason I have, tells me, to be a wife, is to be unhappy, for content seldom in marriage dwells, disturbance keeps possession.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: If you dispraise marriage, you will destroy my hopes, and frustrate my honest design.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Why? what is your design?

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: To be a suitor to you.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: And what is your hopes?

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: To be your husband.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: If I thought marriage were necessary, although unhappy, yet there would be required more wit and judgement in choosing a husband than in dressing myself; wherefore it were requisite, that some of more wit and judgement than myself, should choose for me, otherwise I may be betrayed by flattery, outward garb, insinuations or falsehood, and through an unexperienced innocency, I may take words and shows, for worth and merit, which I pray the gods I may not do; for to marry an unworthy man, were to me to be at the height of affliction, and marriage being unhappy in itself, needs no addition to make it worse.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p:
Madam? Discretion forbids me to commend myself, although I am a lover; for had I merits worthy great praises, it were unfit I should mention them; but there is not any man or woman, that is, or can be exactly known, either by themselves or others; for nature is obscure, she never divulges herself, neither to any creature, nor by, or through any creature; for the hides herself under infinite varieties, changes and chances; she disguises herself with antic vizards, she appears sometimes old, sometimes young, sometimes vaded and withered, sometimes green and flourishing, sometimes feeble and weak, sometimes strong and lusty, sometimes deformed, and sometimes beautiful; sometimes she appears with horror, sometimes with delight, sometimes she appears in glimpsing lights of knowledge,
than clouds herself with ignorance. But, madam, since we are as ignorant of our souls, as of our fortunes, and as ignorant of our lives, as of our deaths; we cannot make any choice upon certainties, but upon uncertainties, and if we be good whilst we live, our deaths will be our witness to prove it; in the mean time, let our promises stand bound for us, which is the best engagement we can give; although it may sail; and let our marriage be as the bond of agreement, although we may forfeit the same, yet let us make it as sure as we can.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: I will consider it, and then I will answer your request.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: That is, to yield.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: It is like enough.

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, and monsieur importunate.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: My fair shrew, are you walking alone.

sp.speaker: Caprisia.
sp.p: My thoughts are my best companions.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Pray, let a thought of me be one of the company.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: When you enter into my mind, you do appear so mean, as my nobler thoughts, scorns that thought that bears your figure.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Thoughts are as notes, and the tongue is the fiddle that makes the music; but your words, as the cords, are out of tune.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: You say so, by reason they are not set to your humour, to sound your praise.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: I say you are very handsome, nature hath given you a surpassing beauty, but pride and self-conceit, hath cast such a shadow, as it hath darkened it, as vaporous clouds doth the bright sun.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Your opinions are cloudy, and your tongue like thunder, strikes my ears with rude, uncivil words.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: I perceive humility, dwells not with beauty, nor with; but is, as great a stranger, as with riches and titles.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and monsieur discretion.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: Madam, the fame of your wit, drew me hither.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: I am sorry my wit hath a greater fame, than my worth, that my vain words should spread further than my virtuous actions, for noble fame is built on worthy deeds.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: But it were pity you should bury your wit in silence; besides, your discourse may profit the hearers, either with delight or instructions.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: O no, for discourses pleases according to the humour, or understanding of the hearers; besides, it is the nature of mankind, to think each other fools, and none but themselves wise; then why should I waste my life to no purpose, knowing times motion swift.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: You do not waste your life through your words, if your words gets you a fame, and esteem of the world.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: What shall I be the better, in having the world's esteem, nay, it is likely that praises (Whilst I live) may do me harm, creating vain and false opinions in my imaginations of self-conceit, of being wiser, or wittier, than really I am; which opinions may make me commit errors, and I had rather the world should laugh at me, for want of wit, than scorn me for my follies.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: But if witty discourses, will get you an esteem, what will your wise actions, and virtuous life; and praise is the reward to all noble endeavours; beside, praise is no burden, but it often serves as a balance, to make the life swim steady in seafaring world: but yet, lady, I would not have your wit outrun your praise, which it will do, if you spur it too hard, for wit must be used like a strong spirited horse, it must be restrained with a bridle, not pricked with the spur, lest it should run away, and fling the rider, which is, the speaker, into a ditch of disgrace; neither must it run wildly about, but must be wrought, to obey the hand and the heel, which is, time and occasion, to stop, and to change, as when to speak, and to whom to speak, and on what to speak, and when to make a stop of silence, otherwise, it will run out of the smooth paths of civility, or the clean ways of modesty: besides, wit must not only be taught, to amble in rhyme, and to trot in prose, but to have a sure footing of sense, and a settled head of reason, lest it should stumble in disputes, or fall into impertinent discourses; likewise, wit may be taught to go in airs of fancies, or low, upon the ground of proof.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: But sir, you must consider, that women are no good managers of wit, for they spoil all their tongue rides on, hackneys it out, until it becomes a dull jade.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: Lest I should give an ill example of tiring in our allegorical discourse, I shall kiss your hands, and take my leave for this time.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Monsieur discretion is a handsome man, he hath a wise countenance, and a manly garo; his discourse is rational and witty, sober and discreet: but good lord! how foolishly I talk to him? I never spoke duller, nor so senselessly, since I was taught words, and he came purposely, as he told me, to hear me speak, and prove my wit; but it was a sign he heard none, for he grew soon a weary of my company, he stayed so short a time: I am troubled often with prating fools, whose visits are as tedious, as their discourses: but lord! why do I condemn others, as fools, when this gentleman, monsieur discretion, hath proved me one.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, and monsieur importunate.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: What? musing by yourself, alone! May I question your ought?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: If you do, you will not be resolved, for there is none at home, to give you an answer.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Why, where are they? wandering abroad?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: They like a brood of birds, are flown out of their nests; for thoughts flies with swifter speed, than time can do, having large wings, of quick desire.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Faith, you are a great wit!

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: You are a great trouble!

div.stage: She offers to go forth, he stays her; she is angry.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: What, you will not force me to stay against my will?

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Yes, that I will; for your father saith, you shall be my wife, and than you will embrace, and kiss me, as coy as you are now.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Which if I do, I wish my arms, when they do wind about your waste, may sting as serpents, and that my kisses may prove poison to your lips.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: What, are you seriously angry; nay, then 'tis time to leave you.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I have heard, that gallant men are civil to our sex, but I have met with none, but rough, rude, rugged natures, more cruel than wild tigers.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Why do you complain of our sex, lady? what is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I would have a gray-headed wisdom, a middle-aged humour, a fresh mouthed wit, a new bloomed youth, and a beauty that every one fancies.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Why, so you have.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Then I have what I desire.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: O! she hath a sharp wit, it is vitral wit.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter madamosel solid, and monsieur Comorade.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Lady, you have killed a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Who, I! why, I never had the courage to kill a fly.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: You have killed him with your disdain.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: I am sorry he had so weak a life, as so slight a cause, as a woman's disdain, could destroy it; but for my part, I disdain no man, although I cannot intimately love all men.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: He is but one man, lady.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: And I have but one particular love to give, or rather I may say, to be gained, for I cannot dispose of it; for it will be only disposed by itself, without my leave, so as I must be guided by that which will not be guided by me? I can lend my pity, but not give him my love.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: I suppose you have given him some encouragement, and hopes, if not an assurance, by reason, he says, you have forsaken him.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Not unless common civility, be an encouragement, and ordinary conversation gives hopes; as for an assurance, indeed I gave monsieur profession; for I did assure him, I could not love him, as he would have me love him, as husband. But, oh vain man! to brag of that he never had.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: 'Tis no brag, lady, to confess he is forsaken.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: It is a brag, for in that he implies, he hath been beloved, for the one must be, before the other.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Pray madam, let me persuade you, to entertain his love, he is a gentleman who hath worth, person and wealth, all which he offers you, as to his goddess, and a good offer is not to be refused, lady, when it may lawfully be taken.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: You say true, sir, and could I persuade my love, as easily as you can commend the man, 'tis likely I should not refuse him.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: But you will be thought cruel, to let a gentleman die, for want of your love.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p:
Why, put the case I have other lovers, as passionate, and worthy as he; how would you have me divide myself amongst them? Or can you
tell me how to please them; I cannot marry them all, the laws forbids it, and to be the common mistress to them, all honour, and honesty forbids it; for though there is some excuse for men, who hath by custom their liberty in amours, because their amours obstructs not nature, so makes breach of honesty; but women are not only barred by nature, but custom of subjection, and modesty of education, wherefore, if they should take liberty to several lovers, or loves courtships, they would not only dishonour themselves, and their whole sex, and their living friends; but their dishonour would outreach their posterity, and run back to their forefathers, that were dead long, long before they were born; for their unchaste lives, would be as marks of disgrace, and spots of infamy upon the tombs of those dead ancestors, and their ashes would be fulled with their stains, whereas, a chaste woman, and a gallant man, obliges both the living, and the dead; for they give honour to their dead ancestors in their graves, and to those friends that are living in the world, and to those that shall succeed them; besides, their examples of their virtues, for all ages to take out patterns from.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Madam, you have answered so well, for yourself, and sex, as I can say no more in the behalf of my friend.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter madam la Mere, and madamosel Caprisia her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Daughter, your tongue is so sharp, as it is not only pointed, but edged on both sides.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Use, mother, will blunt the point, and flat the edges.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: No, daughter, the more 'tis used, the sharper it will be, for words and passions, are the whetstones to that razor.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: As long as that razor shaves no reputation, let it raze, or shave, what it will.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter madamosel solid, madamosel Doltche, madamosel Volante, and a grave matron.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel solid, what say you to monsieur Railleries wit?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: I say of him, as I would of a wild or skittish jade, who hath only strength to kick and fling, but not to travel, or to bear any weight; so raillery, is antic postures, and laughing reproaches, not solid and judicious discourses, or continued speeches, the truth is, a ralleying wit, is like obstructed, or corrupted lungs, which causes difficult, and short breathing; so that wit, is short and puffing, spurting out words, questions and replies; 'tis squib wit, or boys sport

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel Doltche, what say you of monsieur Satirical's wit?

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: As I would of frosty weather; his wit is sharp, but wholesome, and though he hath a frowning brow, yet he hath a clear soul.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel Volante, what say you of monsieur pedants wit.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: As I would of leeches; for as leeches sucks blood from the back parts of men, and spews it forth, when rubbed with salt; so monsieur pedant sucks wit from other men's pens, and mouths, and then spews it forth again; being rubbed with the itch of praise; but all the learned knows, the wit was no more his own, than the blood that was sucked, was the leeches.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What say you of monsieur Lyrics wit?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: As I would of a bird, that chirps more than sings.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel Doltche, what say you of monsieur tragedians wit?

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: As I would of winter, wherein is more rain than sunshines, more storms than calms, more night than day; so his wit, hath more melancholy than mirth, causing, or producing tears, sighs and sadness; the truth is, his wit dwells in the shades of death.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel solid, what say you to monsieur Comicals wit?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: As I would of the spring, which revives, and refreshes the life of every thing, it is lightsome and gay; so monsieur Comicals wit is cheerful, pleasant, lively, natural and profitable, as being edifying.

div.head: Scene 22.
div.stage: Enter madam la Mere, and madamosel Caprisia, her daughter

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Daughter, let me tell you, you have brought your hogs to a fair market.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: That is better, than to keep them in a foul sty, mother.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: You cannot speak without crossing.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Nor readily cross without speaking.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: I am sure, your bitter discourses, and cross answers, hath caused the lady, namely, the lady Hercules, to send a railing message, by a messenger, to declare her anger for your abusive discourses against her.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I never mentioned her in my discourse, in my life.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: But you speak against big, and tall women.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I gave but my opinion of the size, and sex, not of any particular, and I may speak freely, my opinion of the generalities.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: You may chance, by your opinion of the generalities, to be generally talked of.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Why, than I shall live in discourse, although discourse were dead in me, and who had not rather live, although an ill life, than die?

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: But you might live so, as to gain everybody's good opinion, if you would palliate your humour, and sweeten your discourse, and endeavour to please in conversation.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Which do you mean, mother! either to please myself, or the company?

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Why, the company.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: That is impossible, for in all company, there is diversities, and contrarieties of humours, passions, appetites, delights, pleasures, opinions, judgements, wits, understandings, and the like, and for talking, speaking and discoursing, they are interchanging, intermixing, reasoning, arguing disputing, which causes contradictions, wherefore to agree in, and to every humour, passion, opinion, and discourse, is impossible; indeed one may seemly, or truly agree, and approve of any one opinion or discourse; but not a diversity of discourses, opinions; also one may flatteringly applaud, or soothe any particular persons humour, but not divers persons, divers humours, but to flatter, is base, as to approve in their words, and disapprove in their thoughts, as to commend, or applaud that, or those, that is not praiseworthy: but howsoever, for the soothing of anybody's humour, I will never take the pains, for why should I make myself a slave to the several humours of mankind, who is never in one humour two minutes, and why may not I think, or desire to be flattered, and humoured, as well as others, and when I am not flattered, and humoured, to be as much displeased at others, as others at me: wherefore, good mother, be not you displeased, that I chose rather to displease myself, than anybody else, besides yourself.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: You will follow your own ways, daughter.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I cannot walk safer, than in my own ground, mother.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter monsieur perfection, and madamosel solid.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Dear mistress, I fear my absence hath made you forget me.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: No certainly, I cannot forget you, by reason my brain is hung about with the memory of your worthy nature, and meritorious actions; which my love doth admire, and takes delight for to view each several piece and part.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: How can I choose but love, when in my infancy, such a number of words, in your praise, was thrown into my ears, like seeds into the earth, which took root in my heart, from which love sprouted forth, and grew up with my years.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: And will you be constant?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: As day is to the sun!

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: Do you speak truth?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Truly, I have been bred up so much, and so long, in the ways of truth, as I know no tract of dissembling; and therefore, certainly, my words will ever keep within the compass of truth, and my actions will always turn, and run with that bias, but why do you seem to doubt, in making such questions.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: I will truly confess, I have heard, that since I have been in the country, you had entertained another lover.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: It's false, but false reports, is like breathing upon a pure and clear glass, it dims it for a time; but that malicious breath, soon vanishes, and leaves no stain behind it; so I hope your jealousy will do the like, it will vanish, and leave no doubt behind it.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: I hope you are not angry with me, for telling you, or for being myself troubled, at what was reported.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: No, for innocency is never concerned, it always lives in peace and quiet, having a satisfaction in itself, wherefore reports only seizes on the guilty, arresting them with an angry turbulency.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: But, perchance you may be angry for my jealousy.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: No, for jealousy expresses love, as being afraid to lose, what it desires to keep.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: Then, I hope you do not repent the love you have placed on me.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Heaven may sooner repent of doing good, than I repent my love and choice.

sp.speaker: Perfection.
sp.p: Dear mistress, my mind is so full of joy, since it is cleared of suspicion, and assured of your love, as my thoughts doth fly about my brain, like birds in sunshine weather.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter monsieur nobilissimo, and madamosel Doltche.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Sweet lady, will you give me leave to be your servant!

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: I wish I were a mistress worthy of your service.

sp.speaker: Nobiliss.
sp.p: There is no man shall admire more your beauty, and wit, nor be more diligent to your youth, nor shall honour your merits, and love your virtue more than I.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Indeed, I had rather be honoured for my merit, than for my birth, for my breeding, than for my wealth, and I had rather be beloved for my virtue, than admired for my beauty; and I had rather be commended for my silence, than for my wit.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: It were pity you should bury your great wit in silence.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: My wit is according to my years, tender and young.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Your wit, lady, may entertain the silver haired sages.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: No surely, for neither my years, nor my wit, are arrived to that degree, as to make a good companion, having had neither the experience of time, nor practice of speech; for I have been almost a mute hitherto, and a stranger to the world.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: The world is wide, and to travel in it, is both dangerous and difficult; wherefore, you being young, should take a guide, to protect and direct you, and there is no guide nor protector so honourable, and safe, as a husband; what think you of marriage.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Marriage, and my thoughts, live at that distance, as they seldom meet.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Why, I hope you have not made a vow, to live a single life.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: No, for the laws of morality, and divinity, are chains, which doth sufficiently restrain mankind, and ties him into a narrow compass; and though I will not break those chaining laws, to get lose, and so become lawless; yet I will not tie nature harder with vain opinions, and unnecessary vows, than she is tied already.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: You shall need no tutor, for you cannot only instruct yourself, but teach others.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Alas, my brain is like unplanted ground, and my words like wild fruits, or like unprofitable grain, that yields no nourishing food to the understanding; wherefore, if I should offer to speak, my speech must be to ask questions, not to give instructions.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Certainly, lady, nature did study the architectour of your form, and drew from herself the purest extractions, for your mind, and your soul, the essence or spirits of those extractions, or rather you appear to me, a miracle, something above nature, to be so young and beautiful, and yet so virtuous, witty and wise, graced with such civil behaviour; for many a grave beard, would have wagged with talking, less sense, with more words.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Youth and age, is subject to errors, one for want of time to get experience, the other through long time, wherein they lose their memory.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Pray let me get your affections, and then I shall not lose my hopes of a virtuous lady to my wife.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia, and monsieur generosity.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Lady, are you walking studiously alone? may I not be thought rude, if I should ask what your studies are?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I am studying, how some studies for pain, some pleasure, some dangers, some quarrels, some to be wicked, some to be learned, some to be ignorant, some to be foolish, some to be famous, but few to be wise.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies to be wicked?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Thieves, murderers, adulterers, liars, and extortioners.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies to be learned?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Linguists.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies to be ignorant?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Divines.

sp.speaker: Generosity,
sp.p: Who studies quarrels?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies dangers?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies to be fools?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Buffoons.

sp.speaker: Generosity,
sp.p: Who studies fame?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Poets.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies pleasure?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Epicures.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies pain?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Epicures.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Do epicures study both for pain, and pleasure?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Yes, for they that surfeit with pleasure, must endure pain; and epicures studies the height of pleasure, which no sooner enjoyed, but pain follows.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Who studies to be wise?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: They that study temperance, prudence, fortitude and justice.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: And, what study you?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I study how I may avoid the company of mankind, also, to be quit of your lordship's presence.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: She is so handsome, no humour can ill become her.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter monsieur profession, and monsieur Comorade.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Thom. Give me leave to rejoice with thee, for the resurrection of thy heart, that was killed with thy mistress's cruelty, and buried in her constancy.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Well, well? make yourself merry.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: But prithee, in what plight is thy heart? I doubt it is lean, weak and pale, and in a puling condition, lying in the grave of thy mistress's inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot tell; the good angel that brought into life, can give a better account of it, than I can.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Where shall I seek this good angel? amongst the effeminate or masculine sex: for I suppose, it is an angel that is of one sex, although I have heard, angels are of neither sex; but prithee, of which shall I inquire.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Of the divine sex, and the divinest of her sex.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: You may as well bid me inquire of that which is not to be found, for every particular man that is a servant to any particular of these angelical creatures, will prefer his own mistress, to be the divinest, and so the most absolutest.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: All men that sees my mistress, and doth not adore her, as the only she, is damned in ignorance, and condemned to perpetual blindness.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Say you so, than I will not see her, for fear I should be one of the damned, and therefore I will give over that design, as the search of her, and go to a tavern, and drink the good health of thy heart, and leave the inquiry after it, and if you will go with me, so.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: I cannot, without the breach of gratitude, deny thy kindness; wherefore, I will bear thee company.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter doctor freedom, and madamosel Doltche, madamosel solid, madamosel Volante.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: O, you are welcome, doctor freedom.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: If I be not welcome now, I shall never be welcome.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Why, doctor? what present have you brought us? that can make you so acceptable, is it perpetual youth, or undeniable beauty, or everlasting life? But prithee, doctor, what is it that will make thee so welcome?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Why, myself; here being so many young ladies together, and not a man amongst them.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Thyself, doctor! why, thou art not worth the dregs of an urinal, of a sick water, if it were not for our charity, and generosity, more than thy merit, ability or service, you would have but a cold entertainment, and a rule welcome.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, my young, witty, satirical patient, you will take a surfeit of fruit, milk, puddings, pies, or sweetmeats, one of these days, and than you will flatter me.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: You say right, doctor; but now I speak truth, and is not that better than to flatter, or dissemble; for there is none but sick, and depraved souls, that will deliver truth with a quarter, half, or three quartered face, like merchants, or mechanic, that would sell off their ill commodities, with a broken light, but a noble and healthful soul, shows the full face of truth, in a clear light; wherefore, the sick and base, will flatter, but the noble and free, will speak truth.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, I am sure you think better of me in your thoughts, than your words expresses.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Let me tell you, my words and thoughts, are so well acquainted, as they never dissemble, and there is such a friendship betwixt them, as they never move several ways, but runs even together: but let me tell thee, doctor, I have such a spleen to thy sex, as I desire to kill them, at least, to wound them with spiteful words; and I wish I had beauty enough for to damn them, causing them to be perjured, by forsaking other women, they were bound by sacred vows, and holy bonds.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: It is well, master doctor, that you can be privileged amongst the young ladies, at all times, when such as I, that have not your profession, are oftentimes shut, and locked out.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Faith, if you have no better entertainment, than I have had since I came, it were better you were from them, than with them, for their tongues are as sharp as needles.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign we want work, when we are forced to stitch our wit upon you.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: How dare you anger the doctor, when your life lies upon his skill.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: O! his skill lies upon chance, and it is a chance, whether he kills, or cures, is it not, doctor?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: No, for I can kill my patients, when I will, although not cure them, when I will.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Well, then, doctor, when I would die, I will send for you, but not when I would live.

sp.speaker: Discretion.
sp.p: Your servant, ladies.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Good lady wit, follow monsieur discretion, he will make you a wise lady, and make your wit discreet, as it should be.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: O doctor! how you mistake, for wit cannot be made, it is a creator, and not a creature; for wit was the first master, or mistress of arts; the first husbandman, Granger, Gardiner, carver, painter, Graver, caster and moulder, mason, joiner smith, Brasier, Glazier, the first chandler, vintner, brewer, baker, cook, confectioner, the first spinster, weaver, knitter, tailor, shoemaker, and millions the like; also wit was the first navigator, architector, mathematician, logician, geometrician, cosmographer, astronomer, astrologer, philosopher, poet, historian and herald; also wit made the first commonwealth, invented laws for peace, arms for wars, ceremonies for state and religion; also music, dancing, dressing, masking, playing for delight and pleasure; wit divides time, employs time, prevents time, and provides for time; it makes heavens, and hells, gods and devils.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, for though thou hast a heavenly mind, and an angelical beauty, yet thou hast a devilish wit,

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: It shall be sure to torment thee, doctor, but do you hear, doctor? pray present my service to monsieur discretion, and tell him, it was a sign he liked not our company, he made so short a stay.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: He perceived by your usage of me, that if he stayed, you would beat him out of your company, with your two edged tongues; but I will tell him what a raillery you are.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: I hope you will give me a good report, for I have fully charged you.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: You have overcharged me, and therefore it is likely I shall break into exclamations.

div.head: Scene 28.
div.stage: Enter monsieur importunate, and madamosel Caprisia.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Lady, if I may not be your husband, pray let there be a friendship between us?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: What kind of friendship would you make? for there are so many, and of such different natures, as I know not which you would be; as some friendship is made by beauty, some by flattery, some by luxury, some by factions, others by knavery, and all for interest.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: None for love?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: No, but some are made by lust, but they last not long.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: And is there no friendship made by virtue?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: O no, for virtue may walk all the world over, and meet never a friend, which is the cause she lives alone; for all the world thinks her too rigid for society, which makes mankind adhere to her enemy vice.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: Doth not marriage make a friendship?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Very seldom, for marriage is like a commonwealth, which is a contract of bodies, or rather a contract of interest, not a friendship betwixt souls, and there is as much faction, and oftener civil wars in marriage, than in public commonwealths.

sp.speaker: Importunate.
sp.p: I desire our friendship may be Platonic.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: That is too dangerous, for it oft-times proves a traitor to chastity.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter monsieur nobilissimo, madamosel Doltche, and her nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Sir, you must give me leave to chide you, for staying so long with my nurse-child, as you keep her from her dinner, either go away, or stay and dine with her.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Good nurse, be patient, for though I am engaged to dine with other company; yet her discourse is such charming music, as I have not power to go from her, as yet.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: If my discourse sounds musical, 'tis only when you are by, but when you are absent, the strings of my voice, or speech, is as if they were broken, for then my tongue is out of tune, and my wit is out of humour.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p:
My dearest and sweetest mistress, may your merits be rewarded
by fame, your virtue by heaven, your life by nature, and all your earthly desires by fortune.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: And my love by the return of yours:

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: When I forsake you, may hell take my soul, and devils torment it for ingratitude and perjury.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and a grave matron.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Madamosel Doltche seems to be a very fine, sweet lady, well-behaved, sober, modest, discreet, and of a gentle nature.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Most commonly, every one seems best at the first sight, by reason they put on their civilest demeanours, gracefullest garbs, modestest countenance, and speaks their most choicest phrases, or words, when they meet strangers; all which, makes them appear to their advantage, when after acquaintance, they will seem but vulgar, as when they are used to their ordinary garbs, countenances and phrases, and that their natures and dispositions were known, they will appear to be no better than their neighbours; nay, perchance not so good; the like will madamosel Doltche appear to you.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I do suppose she looks more familiar on her acquaintance, than strangers, and it is likely, she looks more grave, and sober on strangers, than on her known friends, and familiars; yet those several looks and countenances, may be as pleasing, and obliging, the one, as the other; for though the one may be more kind, the other may be more respectful; for every ones countenance and behaviour, is to be ordered according to the several degrees or relations of several persons, and to several persons, and to several sexes, or according to their condition, state, life and fortune, and according to the times and occasions; for women are, or should be, more free and confident to, and in the company of women, than men; and men are more respectful in their discourse and behaviour to women, than to their own sex, and a merry countenance in a sad condition or state of life or fortunes, would not be seemly; mirth in the house of mourning, would be inhumane, or to dance or sing over the graves of their parents, children, husbands, wives or friends, would be unnatural, or to be merry in the time of a general calamity, as in time of wars, plagues, or famine, or deluges, or to be sad or froward in a general rejoicing; but a sad countenance, and a grave behaviour, is as fitting, and seems comely and handsome in a time of calamity, as a merry countenance, and a dancing behaviour, in a time of rejoicing; for tears becomes the face, sometimes, as well as smiles, and blushing may appear and express a modest nature to strangers, when to familiar acquaintances, blushing might be thought an accuser, or witness of some crime, yet bashful eyes at all times, becomes modest virgins.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p:
I hate bashful eyes, for they are like to troubled waters, thick and unsteady, rolling from place to place, without an assurance; for modest virgins may look upon the world with a confident brow, if they have no guilt to stain their cheeks with blushes, and surely amongst well-bred persons,
there is none so rude, injurious, or uncivil, to force the blood to rise, or stop the light, in causing bashful eyes, but such as condemns a confident countenance in virgin's faces; my eye of understanding will cast a despising glance on such ridiculous fools, and the tongue of reason condemns them.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter madam la Mere, and madamosel Caprisia her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: I wonder, daughter, you should be so rudely uncivil to monsieur generosity, to use him so unkindly, as to entertain him with scornful words, and disrespectful behaviour.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Why did he come to visit me?

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: To offer his service, and to profess his affection to your person and virtue.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I care not for his service, or affection.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: But he is a person of an honourable title, and can make you a great lady.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Give me leave to tell you, mother, that nature hath given me titles of honour, wit and beauty, to which all men will bow to, with respect; titles from Kings, poor petty things to those.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: But daughter, let me tell you, that wit and beauty, without modesty, civility and virtuous courtesy, may ensnare facile fools, and allure fond persons, but not persuade the judicious to esteem you, nor the constant to sue to you, nor true love to desire you; you may have vain boasters, and amorous flatterers to court you; but none that is wise, or honourable, will marry you, and to use this noble lord so disrespectfully, who is endued with virtue, and adorned with the graces, and beloved of the Muses, is a crime unpardonable.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Mother, the Muses and the graces are witches, which enchants the soul, and charms the spirits, and makes the senses extravagant, and the actions desperate.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Methinks they should charm you; if they have such power.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: My humour is a spell against all such charms.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter monsieur profession, and monsieur Comorade his friend.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: You are well met, for I was going to your lodging to see you.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: And I am now going home, and therefore let us go together.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Where have you been?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: At a house you often resort to.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: What, at a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Why, how durst you venture?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Why! why if your angelical mistress should come to hear of it; faith, she would bury your heart again.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Yes, is it were not out of her power.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Why, hath she not the possession?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: No saith.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: How comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: I know not how, but upon some dislike, it grew weary, and by some opportunity, it found it stole home, and since it hath promised never to leave me again; for it hath confessed to me, it hath been most miserably tormented with doubts, fears, jealousies and despairs.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Prithee let me tell thee, as a friend, that thy heart, is a false lying heart, for there inhabits no torments amongst angelical bodies.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: By your favour, in Pluto's court, there be angels as well, and as many as in Jove's; but let me tell you, that if I did not love you very well, I would call you to an account, for calling my heart, a false lying heart.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Prithee pacify thyself, for I am sure I have had but a heartless friend of thee, all the time of thy heart's absence, and if I should rail of thy heart, thou hast no reason to condemn me; but prithee, tell me, had not thy heart some pleasure sometimes to mitigate the torments?

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: No saith, for my heart tells me, that what with rigid virtue, cruel scorn, and insulting pride, it never had a minute's pleasure, nor so much as a moment of ease; and if that there were no more hopes of happiness amongst the gods in heaven, than there is amongst the goddesses on earth, it would never desire to go to them, or dwell amongst them: nay, my heart says, it should be as much afraid to go to heaven, and to be with the gods, as mortals are to go to hell, to be with devils.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: But if pleasure, and happiness, is not to be found with virtue, nor with the gods, where shall we seek for it.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: I will tell you what my heart saith, and doth assure me; that is, that pleasure lives always with vice, and that good fellowship is amongst the damned, and it doth swear, it is a most melancholy life, to live with those that are called the blessed, which are the goddesses on earth.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Why, then let us return to the house from whence you came.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: No faith, I am dry, wherefore I will go to a tavern.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Content.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Caprisia alone, in a studeous humour, walking for a time silently; then speaks.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Which shall I complain of? Nature or education; I am compassionate by nature; for though I am froward, I am not cruel, I am pious by education; for though I am froward, I am not wicked, I am virtuous by nature, and education; for though I am froward, I am neither dishonest, unchaste, base, or unworthy: why then, 'tis fortune I must complain of, for fortune hath given me plenty, and plenty hath made me proud, and pride hath made me self-conceited, self-conceit hath bred disdain, and disdain scorn; so pride, disdain, and scorn, makes me disapprove all other creatures actions, or opinions, but my own; and this disapproving is that which men calls cross, peevish, and froward disposition, being most commonly, accompanied with sharp satirical words, and angry frowns.
sp.l: These faults I'll conquer, wheresoe'er they lie;
I'll rule my froward humour, or I'll die.

div.head: Scene 34.
div.stage: Enter madamosel solid, and a matron.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Lord! Lord! I wonder men and women should spend their time so idly, and waste their lives so vainly, in talking so ignorantly, and acting so foolishly upon the great stage, or the stage of the great world.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why, how would you have them spend their time, or talk, or act?

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p:
I would have them spend their time, to gain time, as to prevent or hinder times oblivion, and to speak and act to that design,
— that when their bodies die,
Their names and fames, may live eternally.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But it is not in every man's, or woman's power, to get fame, for some are made uncapable by nature, others are hindered by fortune, some are obstructed by chance, others want time and opportunity, wealth, birth and education, and many that are pulled back by envy, spite and malice.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p:
What man or woman soever, that nature is liberal to, may eternalise themselves; as for fortune, she may hinder the active, the like may chance, envy, spite and malice, but cannot hinder the contemplative; the like may time and opportunity; but poor poverty and birth, can be no hindrance to natural wit, for natural wit, in a poor cottage, may spin an afterlife, interweaving several coloured fancies, and threads of opinions, making fine and curious tapestries to hang in the chambers of fame, or wit may
and carve images of imaginations, to place and set forth the gardens of fame, making fountains of poetry, that may run in smooth streams of verse, or wit may paint and pencil out some copies, and various pictures of nature, with the pencils of rhetoric on the grounds of philosophy, to hang in the galleries of fame; thus the palaces of fame may be furnished and adorned by the wit of a poor cottager.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Item, I am to be courteous, but not familiar; to be merry, but not wild; to be kind, but not wanton, to be friendly, but not intimate; to be sociable, but not troublesome; to be conversable, but not talkative; to look soberly, but not frowningly; to return answers civilly, to ask questions wisely, to demand rights honestly, to argue rationally, and to maintain opinions probably: these rules I will strictly observe, and constantly practice.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Sir, I cry peccavi, and ask your pardon, for speaking so unhandsomely of the effeminate sex, when I was last in your company; for my indiscretion made me forget, so as not to remember, that all men hath either wives, sisters, daughters or mothers: but truly, my discourse proceeded neither from spite or malice, but from the consideration of my own faults, which being so many, did bury the good graces of other women, for though I am virtuously honest, yet I am but rudely fashioned, and untoward for conversation; but though my discourse had a triangular countenance, for it seemed foolish, spiteful and wicked; yet pray, sir, believe, the natural face, was a perfect, round, honest face.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Lady, what faults soever, your sex is guilty of, your virtues will get their pardon, and your beauty will cover their blemishes.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I wish my indiscretion had not discovered my froward imperfections, but I am sorry, and shall hereafter endeavour to rectify my errors.

div.head: Scene 36.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Good nurse, where is my virtuous, sweet mistress?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: In her chamber, sir.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: What is she doing?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: She is reading.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: What books doth she read? are they divinity, morality, philosophy, history or poetry?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Sometimes her study is of one, and then of another; but now I think, her chief study, is you, wherein she may read humanity.

div.stage: Enter madamosel Doltche, and seeing Monsieur nobilissimo with her nurse, starts back, and then comes forth blushing.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Lord child! what makes you blush?

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Not crimes, but my blushing, is caused by a sudden assault, or surprisal meeting him; I did not expect to meet at this time, which raised up blushes in my face; for blushing is like the full and falling tide; for the blood flows to the face, and from thence ebbs to the heart, as passions moves the mind;
sp.l: And thoughts as waves, in curling folds do rise,
And lashful eyes, are like the troubled skies.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Sweet mistress, crimes cannot stain your cheeks with blushes, but modesty hath penciled roses there, which seems as sweet, as they look fair.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: I desire my looks and countenance, may always appear so, as they may never falsely accuse me; and as I would not have my looks, or countenance, wrong my innocency, or deceive the spectators, so I would not have my heart be ungrateful to bury your presence in silence; wherefore, I give you thanks, sir, for the noble present you sent me today.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: I was afraid you would not have accepted of it.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Truly, I shall refuse no present you shall send me, although it were ushered with scorn, and attended with death.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: My kind mistress, I shall never send you any present, but what is ushered by my love, attended by my service, and presented with the offer of my life.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Child, you are very free of kind words.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: And my deeds shall answer my words, is need requires; yet I am sorry if my speaking overmuch, should offend; but I chose rather, to set bosses of words on the sense of my discourse, although it obscures the gloss of my speech, than my love should be buried in my silence.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
