sp.p: Sweet mistress, your loving expressions gives such joy unto my heart, and such delight unto my hearing, as my soul is enthroned in happiness, and crowned with tranquillity.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Pray heaven, you both may be as full of love, joy and peace, when you are married, as you express to have now; but let me tell you, young lovers, that Hymen is a very temperate, and discreet gentleman in love, I will assure you; neither doth he express himself in such high poetical raptures, for his discourse is plain, and ordinary.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Nay, sometimes his discourse is extraordinary, as when he hath wars; but nurse, thou art old, and the fire of love, if ever thou hadst any, is put out by old father times extinguisher.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: True love never dies, nor can time put it out.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but nurse seems by her speech, as if she had never known true love; for true love, as it always burns clear, so it always flames high, far infinite is the fuel that feeds it.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p:
Well, well? young lovers, be not so confident, but let me advise
you to balance reason on both sides, with hopes, and doubts, and then the judgement will be steady.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: But in the scales of love, nurse, nothing must be but confidence.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yes, there must be temperance, or love will surfeit, and die with excess.

sp.speaker: Doltche.
sp.p: Love cannot surfeit, no more than souls with grace, or saints of heaven.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: My smiles shall be as baits, my eyes as angels, where every look shall be a hook to catch a heart; I'll teach my tongue such art, to plant words on each heart, as they shall take deep root, from whence pure love shall spring; my lips shall be as flowery banks, whereon sweet rhetoric grows, and cipherous fancy blows; from which banks, love shall wish to gather posies of kisses, where every single kiss shall differ as roses, pinks, violets, primroses, and daffidillies, and the breath therefrom, shall be as fragrant as the touch, soft thereon, and as the sun doth heat the earth, so shall my embraces heat my lovers thoughts with self-conceit, which were before like water, frozen with a dejected and despairing cold. Hay ho!

div.head: Scene 38.
div.stage: Enter monsieur profession, and madamosel solid.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Dear mistress, you are the only she that is fit to be crowned; the sole empress of the world.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: Let me tell you, sir? I had rather be a single shepherdess, than the sole empress of the world; for I would not be a mistress of so much power, to be as a servant to so much trouble.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: But, put the case Alexander were alive, and would crown you empress of the world, you would not refuse that honour, but accept of it, for the sake of renown.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p:
Yes, I should refuse it, for if I could not get renown by my own merits, I should wish to die in oblivion, for I care not; nay, I despise such
honours and renowns, as comes by derivations, as being derived from another, and not inherent in myself, and it is a poor, and mean renown, that is gained or got, only by receiving a gift from a fellow-creature, who gives out of passion, appetite, partiality, vainglory, or fear, and not for merit or worthsake; wherefore, no gifts but those that comes from the gods, or nature, are to be esteemed, or received with thanks, but were to be refused, had man the power to choose, or to deny.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Sweet mistress, nature hath crowned you with beauty and wit, and the god's hath given you a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: I wish they had, for the god's gifts are not like to man's, and nature's crown is beyond the golden crown of art, which are greater glories, than power, wealth, title or birth, or all the outward honours gained on earth; but I desire the gods may crown my soul with reason and understanding; heaven crown my mind with temperance and fortitude; nature crown my body with health and strength, time crown my life with comely and discreet age; death crown my separation with peace and rest; and fame crown my memory with an everlasting renown; thus may my creation be to a happy end.

sp.speaker: Profession.
sp.p: Gods, fortune and fates hath joined to make me happy in your love, and that which will make me absolutely happy, is, that I shall marry you, and embrace you as my wife.

sp.speaker: Solid.
sp.p: The absolute happiness is, when the god's embraces man with mercy, and kisses him with love.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Hay, ho! who can love, and be wise? but why do I say so? For reason loves wisely; 'tis only the mistaken senses that loves foolishly; indeed, the sense doth not love, but fondly, and foolishly affects, for it, 'tis an humoursome and inconstant appetite that proceeds from the body, and not that noble passion of true love which proceeds from the soul: but o! what a ridiculous humour am I fallen into, from a choleric humour, into an amorous humour; oh! I could tear my soul from my body, for having such whining thoughts, and such a mean, submissive, croaching, feigning, flattering humour, and idle mind; a choleric humour, is noble to this, for it is commanding, and seems of an heroic spirit, but to be amorous, is base, beastly, and of an inconstant nature.
sp.l: Oh! how apt is busy life to go amiss,
What foolish humours in man's mind there is:
But o! the soul is far beyond the mind,
As much as man is from the beastly kind.

div.head: Scene 40.
div.stage: Enter madamosel Volante, and doctor freedom.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Are you weary of, your life? that you send me; for you said, you would not send for me, until you had a desire to die.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: True, doctor, and if you cannot cure me, kill me.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: In my conscience, you have sent for me to play the wanton.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Why, doctor? If I do not infringe the rules and laws of modesty, or civility, I cannot commit wanton faults,

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Yes faith, your tongue may play the wanton,

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Indeed, doctor, I had rather tell a wanton truth, than a modest lie.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, what is your disease?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Nay, that you must guess, I can only tell my pains.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Where is your pain?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: In my heart and head.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Those be dangerous parts, but after what manner are your pains?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: On my heart there lies a weight, as heavy as the world on Atlas' shoulders; and from my melancholy mind, arises such damps of doubts, as almost quenches out the fire of life, did not some hope, though weak, which blows with fainting breath, keep it alive, or rather puffs than blows, which intermitting motions, makes my pulse unequal, and my blood to ebb and flow, as from my heart, unto my face; and from my face, unto my heart again; as for my head, it feels drowsy, and my spirits are dull; my thoughts uneasily doth run, crossing, and striving to throw each other down; this causes broken sleeps, and frightful dreams, and when I awake at every noise, I start with fears, my limbs doth shake.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Why, this disease is love, wherefore I cannot cure you; for love no more than wit, can neither be tempered, nor yet be ruled, for love and wit, keeps neither moderate bounds, nor spares diet, but dies most commonly of a surfeit.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: O yes, discretion can cure both.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Then send for monsieur discretion, and hear what he says to you, for your disease is passed my skill.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: By your industry, doctor, help may be found, in giving directions, and ordering the cordial.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: So I understand you would have my counsel what you should do, and my industry to order, and get a meeting between monsieur discretion and you, and to make the match betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: You understand me right.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, I will study the means, and try if I can procure thee a man.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Good fortune be your guide.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: And monsieur discretion, your husband,

div.head: Scene 41.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: Thoughts be at rest, for since my love is honest, and the person I love worthy, I may love honourably, for he is not only learned with study, experienced with time and practice, but he is nature's favourite, she hath endued his soul with uncontrolled reason, his mind with noble thoughts, his heart with heroic generosity, and his brain with a supreme wit; besides, she hath presented his judgement and understanding, with such a clear prospective-glass of speculations, and such a multiplying-glass of conception, as he seeth farther, and discerns more into nature's works, than any man she hath made before him.

div.stage: She slops a little time, then speaks.

sp.p: But let me consider? I have used this worthy gentleman uncivilly, nay rudely, I have despised him; wherefore he cannot love me, for nature abhors neglect, and if he cannot love me in honesty, he ought not to marry me, and if I be not his wife, for certain I shall die for love, or live a most unhappy life, which is far worse than death. Hay ho!

div.stage: Enter madam la Mere her mother.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: What, daughter, sick with love?

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: O, mother? love is a tyrant, which never lets the mind be at rest, and the thoughts are the torments, and when the mind is tormented, the body is seldom in health.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Well, to ease you, I will go to this lord generosity, and pray him to give you a visit.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: By no means, mother, for I had rather die with love, than live to be despised with scorn, for he will refuse your desires, or if he should come, it would be but to express his hate, or proudly triumph on my unhappy state.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: She is most desperately in love, but I will endeavour to settle her mind.

div.head: Scene 42.
div.stage: Enter doctor freedom, and madamosel Volante.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Am not I a good doctor now, that hath got you a good husband?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Nay, doctor, he is but a suitor, as yet.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Why do not you woe upon the stage, as the rest of your comorades doth?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: O fie, doctor discretion never whines our love in public.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: So you love to be in private?

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Why, doctor, the purest love is most concealed, it lies in the heart; and it warms itself by its own fire.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Take heed, for if you keep it too tenderly, and close, it may chance to catch cold when it comes abroad.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: True love ought to keep home, and not to gossip abroad.

sp.speaker: Servant-maid.
sp.p: Madam monsieur discretion is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Come, doctor, be a witness of our contract?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I had rather stay with your maid.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: She hath not wit to entertain you.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Nor none to anger me.

sp.speaker: Volante.
sp.p: Pray come away, for no wise man is angry with wit.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I perceive, if I do not go with you, that you will call me fool.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter monsieur Comorade, and monsieur bon compaignon.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Comorade, what cause makes you so fine today?

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: I am going to two weddings today.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Faith, one had been enough; but how can you divide yourself betwixt two bridals?

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: I shall not need to divide myself, since the bridals keeps together; for they are married both in one church, and by one priest, and they feast in one house.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: And will they lie in one bed?

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: No surely, they will have two beds, for fear each bridegroom should mistake his bride.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Well, I wish the bridegrooms, and their bride's joy, and their guests, good cheer.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Will not you be one of the guests?

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: No, for a bon compaignon shuns Hymen's court, neither will Hymen entertain him: but who are the brides and bridegrooms?

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: Monsieur Nobilissimo, and madamosel Doltche, and monsieur perfection; and madamosel solid.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: Is monsieur profession a guest there.

sp.speaker: Comorade.
sp.p: No, for he swears now, that he hates marriage, as he hates death.

sp.speaker: Bon compaignon.
sp.p: But he loves a mistress, as he loves life.

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter monsieur generosity, and madamosel Caprisia; he following her.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Lady, why do you shun my company, in going from me, praystay, and give my visit a civil entertainment; for though I am not worthy of your affection, yet my love deserves you civility.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I know you are come to laugh at me, which is ignobly done; for heroic, generous spirits, doth not triumph on the weak effeminate sex.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: Pray believe I am a gentleman, for if I loved you not, yet I would never be rude, to be uncivil to you, or your sex; but I love you so well, as when I leave to serve you with my life, may nature leave to nourish me, fortune leave to favour me, and heaven leave to bless me, and then let death cast me into hell, there to be tormented.

sp.speaker: Capris.
sp.p: I am more obliged to your generous affections, than to my own merits.

sp.speaker: Generosity.
sp.p: The ill opinion of yourself doth not lessen your virtues, and if you think me worthy to be your husband, and will agree, we will go straight to church, and be married.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.p: I shall not refuse you.
